text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives in a small apartment on the 30th floor of a high-rise building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator to the 15th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining 15 floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way up to the 30th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I need to figure out why this man takes the elevator all the way up to the 30th floor on rainy days.
Let me break this down step by step.
First, let's understand his usual routine.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down from the 30th floor to the ground floor (which is floor 1) to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator up to the 15th floor and then walks up the remaining 15 floors to his apartment.
So, on normal days, he doesn't take the elevator all the way up; he only uses it part of the way and walks the rest.
Now, on rainy days, he changes his routine.
Instead of getting off at the 15th floor and walking up, he stays on the elevator all the way to the 30th floor.
That means he's taking the elevator for a longer distance both in the morning and evening on rainy days.
I wonder why this would be beneficial.
Maybe it's about avoiding the stairs on rainy days.
Walking up 15 floors in the rain could be slippery and uncomfortable.
By taking the elevator all the way, he avoids the potential hazards of walking up the stairs in the rain.
Another thought is about time.
Maybe the elevator is faster than walking up the stairs, especially on a rainy day when he's already going down in the morning.
But I'm not sure if that's the main reason because he's taking the elevator both ways.
If it's faster, he might do it every day, not just on rainy days.
Wait, maybe it's about saving time in the morning.
He's already taking the elevator down, so if he takes it all the way up in the evening, he avoids walking up the stairs.
That would save him time and effort, especially on rainy days when walking might be slower or more tiring.
But why wouldn't he do this every day? Maybe the elevator isn't always available or it's faster to walk part of the way.
Or perhaps he prefers the exercise of walking up the stairs on nice days.
Alternatively, maybe the building has a policy about taking the elevator all the way, but that doesn't seem likely.
The question is more about his personal preference.
So, putting it all together, the main reason seems to be that on rainy days, he wants to avoid walking up the stairs, which can be slippery and uncomfortable.
Therefore, he takes the elevator all the way up to the 30th floor to stay dry and safe.
I think that's the most plausible explanation.
He's making a choice to use the elevator on rainy days to prevent the inconvenience and potential danger of walking up the stairs in the rain.

</think>

The man takes the elevator all the way up to the 30th floor on rainy days to avoid walking up the slippery stairs, ensuring he stays dry and safe.
